So take it away, David. DAVID TAMES: Glad to be here. Thanks, Chris. So as Chris said, we're going
to talk about basic lighting.

And we're going to use a simple
straightforward interview as the subject of our

Today, of course, there's a lot
of things that we can light. But basically, interview

Just since we're at MIT, we
need to talk a little bit about what light is. It's a tiny sliver of the
electromagnetic spectrum

that our eyes are sensitive to. As the wavelengths
get shorter, you end up with things like
X-rays and gamma rays.

And as the wavelengths
get longer, we end up with radio waves, just
like this wireless mic going on

here. But this tiny, tiny, tiny sliver
of the electromagnetic spectrum is what our eyes happen
to be sensitive to.

And this is the medium
that we are working with. These are our materials that
we work with in film and video.

And of course, there's
that classic experiment that Newton did in his-- I guess it was his
grandmother's barn or something.

Not only did he-- it was well known
at his time that you could break white light
into the constituency

of the various colors
of the rainbow. But he also showed that once you
broke it down to those colors,

you couldn't break
it down any further and that with a second prism,
you could recombine that light

back into white light. So it turns out that working
with any combination of red,

green, and blue light, we
can create any of the colors that we're sensitive to. And so interestingly enough,
most of our imaging systems

today basically work with red,
green, and blue receptors, which we will talk about
why red, green, and blue

happens to be the star colors
from which all other colors can be derived.

And it turns out that our
eyes have receptors sensitive in the blue range, the green
range, and the red range.

And we are most sensitive
to those in the green range. Perhaps our ancestors
who could see green

were more successful
than our ancestors who were primarily sensitive
to other frequencies of light.

Who knows about that. But enough technical stuff. When we talk about
light creatively, we're not thinking
about wavelengths

and the individual
colors that much, but we're thinking about
certain characteristics.

We often talk about intensity,
how bright is the light. And it turns out that since
most light sources radiate

in all directions, there's very,
very rapid falloff of light. So we call that the
inverse square law.

So if you're by a window and
you have a really, really nice exposure, walking
away from the window just a little bit is enough
to end up in darkness.

Because if you
double the distance between the light
and the subject, you only have one fourth
of the intensity as before.

So you're always working
against the inverse square law

in terms of the intensity. So if you need your
light to be brighter, you can always move it
closer to your subject

or get a bigger light. We also talk about
the quality of light, whether it's hard or soft.

Hard light has bold
shadows, crisp textures. We'll look at an example
in just a moment. And soft light has
a gentle contrast.

It's more diffused, typically
very soft or no shadows. We often talk about
the direction of light.

Where is it coming from? It refers to the
path of the light from the source of the
light to our subject.

Is it coming from the
front, the side, the back, under light, top light? And we use these
terms to describe

where the light comes from. And of course, color, like we
just saw in the previous slide,

it's the relative
mix of wavelengths. And color is often motivated
by the light source.

So if we want to
depict a sunny day, we use yellows and very,
very light blues and white.

It can establish mood. So if we're going
to-- typically, period pieces that take
places during the Renaissance

orange glow about them. Just last night I

Perhaps since the primary light

But that was magical that you

you end up with
white light as well. Because if you have equal

and blue light, then we
see what we call white. And so I would suggest

working with-- often, we want to change the
color of a light source.

And we'll put something
called a gel over that light. And when we're doing
that, we're using

what we call the
subtractive light model. In other words,
we're filtering out some of the wavelengths
and not others.

So it turns out that if you put
yellow, cyan, and magenta gels, which happen to be the
complements of red, green,

and blue, but if you put those
three gels over a light table, for example, you will
see that you end up

with this muddy brown
darkness where they overlap because you have
pretty much filtered

out all of the light sources. They're not perfect filters,
so that black will never

be totally black. This is why in four color
printing of magazines and newspapers, they use
cyan, magenta, yellow,

and black ink for
that extra blackness. So that also uses the
subtractive system.

So you can either
use pigments or you can use gels to subtract
particular wavelengths. So for example, if my scene
was a little too orangey

and I wanted my light sources
to be a little less orangey, I would be putting different
gradations of blue gels

over those lights, for example. So that's the subtractive model. And once you get to know
this, it makes perfect sense.

And we'll talk a little
more about blue and orangey correction gels, which
we have a tendency

to use a lot in film video work,
because we're often correcting or changing the light
from the cool blues

to the warmer orangey lights. But that's the
subtractive model at work.

So it turns out
that video cameras being technical devices,
they don't really

know what white is. Some combination of red, green,
and blue wavelengths is white. But your white might be
different than my white,

might be different than
that Sony camera's white. So what we typically do when
we white balance the camera

is we point the camera
and hold up a white card. And we push the
white balance button. And we're telling the camera,
that particular combination

of red, green, and blue,
whatever it happens to be, that's my white reference. And now the camera
will display whatever

that card is as pure white. Well, it turns out that
this relative balance

of red, green, and
blue, the camera sees it as a technical
problem to solve. And very often, the perfect
white balance of a camera

is often maybe a little too
clean, too dry, too perfect.

So a trick that I do
is I get something called an eighth blue gel, which
is like a very pale blue gel.

And when I white
balance my camera, I hold that pale blue
gel over the camera lens, I press the white
balance button,

and I push away the gel. And what have I done? I have fooled the camera
into thinking that there's

more blue in the world. And it compensates by
making the image a teeny bit warmer, a little more orangey.

And flesh tones
look a lot better with just a little
bit of warmth added.

So this is my
little bit of basil in the sauce for a

You will hear a lot of people
talk about color temperature. This is a method that
is used to describe what

the color of a light source is. We work so often in this orange
to blue to white dimension

simply because so many of our
artificial and natural light sources are in that range.

For example, fire,
candle, matches, they're all kind of orange. Sunlight is very blue.

And so it turns out that color
temperature is basically,

what temperature do
you need to heat up this theoretical black
body radiator in order

to get that color? Well, it turns out in
practical everyday world, that black body
radiator that you've

read in cinematography
books, the equivalent, think of it as a tungsten
filament, as a light filament.

The more juice you put through
that filament, the less orangey it is and the more
white it becomes.

Of course, at some point,
it explodes because it's handling too much current. But in theory, if you heated
it up to 9,000 degrees,

you would have the same color
as hazy sunlight, which is very, very pale blue, almost white.

But if you bring the temperature
down to 1,700 degrees Kelvin, you would have the nice,
orangey color of a match flame.

So this is this
temperature scale from orangey on the
low temperature end

to almost perfect white
with a slight tinge of blue on the high end. There are two magic
numbers that you

hear in the world of white
balance, 3,200 degrees Kelvin, which is the industry
standard for tungsten filament

incandescent lights. It is the standard that for
almost 100 years, well, maybe

80 years, film emulsions
were matched to that color temperature, so that something
lit under 3,200 degree

Kelvin light would look white. There's also daylight
balanced films. So consumer film
was usually balanced

to 5,500 degrees Kelvin. And that's called
daylight balance. So most electronic flash
is balanced for daylight,

and consumer film was always
mostly balanced for daylight.

And of course, now in the error
of video and digital imaging, it's a little bit of a holdover.

But we still use these terms
because film lighting still comes primarily in
two flavors, tungsten

balanced, quartz halogen lamps,
LED lamps, fluorescent lamps, et cetera. They're all available matched
perfectly 3,200 degrees Kelvin.

And a new generation of HMI
daylight balanced lights, daylight balanced fluorescents,
daylight balanced LEDs,

they're available
matched perfectly to 5,500 degrees Kelvin. PROFESSOR: And also many
cameras that you may use have

preset white balance settings. So there may be
one for daylight. There may be one for tungsten.

And when you click it
to one of those settings rather than create
the white balance yourself, as David
just described,

essentially what you're
doing is the equivalent of loading your camera with
an emulsion that's balanced

to one of those presets. So 3,200 is, in theory,
perfectly balanced

for tungsten light. And the daylight balance is
perfectly balanced, in theory, for about 5,500, 5,600.

Because shadows don't

the way the eye sees it unless you do some

So often, we're
splitting the difference between tungsten interior
lighting and daylight

streaming through windows. On a big Hollywood

to maybe gel those windows and
put orange gel over the windows so that now everything

As documentary
makers, we typically don't have a crew that can gel

to set the white
balance for our scene. And of course, sunsets

the same dimensions

we're looking at, red,
green, and blue pixels. And with our cameras, we have

sensors. So if our scene is a little too

while we're shooting? The reason is you want
to get the white balance

right the first time when you
shoot because if the scene is excessively blue or the
scene is excessively orange,

what happens is you're going
to overexpose the red channel or overexpose the blue channel.

And what happens is once you
overexpose that color channel, there's no information or detail
to bring back when you correct.

So you will always notice
that a properly white balance scene, you can
fine tune the color and get a very
rich, sensual image.

But if you shoot the
wrong white balance and you go in to
correct, you're going to notice that your
detail looks different

and your highlights don't have
the same texture and detail. Because if you shot, for

in a tungsten environment,
you have completely whacked out the red channel
relative to the green and blue

channels. So you do want to get it right. Because having one
channel way overexposed,

that detail is lost forever. So yes, you can correct in post,

of the road starting
point in production. I want to revisit

with direct sunlight, you get very, very hard,

crisp, clean shadows. Whereas on an overcast

have been creating a
